Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Identification of magnetic sources in the upper mantle
Award.AbstractNarration:
The view that the upper mantle is universally non-magnetic because it lacks ferromagnetic minerals and would be too hot to carry a magnetic remanence needs to be revisited because converging evidence suggests that some magnetic sources reside at mantle depths. This situation occurs in cold geotherm settings. We propose to carefully measure the magnetic properties of mantle xenoliths using new collections of fresh mantle rocks. The magnetic measurements will be supported by thorough petrologic investigations and by experiments in piston cylinders replicating the rapid ascent of mantle rocks to the Earth surface. The results these investigations will most likely transform the interpretation of data returned by the Swarm mission, deployed in November 2013, which will provide an unprecedented resolution of the lithospheric magnetic field.

Our understanding of the internal structure of the Earth relies on geophysical approaches including for example seismology, gravimetry and magnetism. The magnetic field at the Earth's surface informs us about temperature at depth because below the Curie depth, minerals become too hot to be magnetic. Up to now, we thought that mantle rocks, at depths of about 30 kilometers, did not carry any magnetic minerals, an assumption based on measurements made in the 1980?s. The proposed research will re-evaluate this non-magnetic mantle concept and provide a far more accurate knowledge base to interpret magnetic satellite data. The information deduced from magnetic satellites provides vital information on regions of the globe where tectonic plates collide and create abundant seismicity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mantle of the Earth is the layer immediately underneath the crust, both in continents and oceans. This layer, made of rocks named peridotites, is hard to access because it sits at depths of 30 km and more. Small fragments of the mantle, called xenoliths, occasionally come up to the Earth surface through volcanoes that rip  these pieces from the mantle. Up until our study, we thought that the mantle was a non-magnetic layer because at greath depths the Earth’s internal heat demagnetized minerals and rocks and also because scientists thought that the mineral magnetite was absent from this layer. We found quite the opposite. We have collected over 400 xenoliths from all over the world and found magnetite in almost all of them. The abundance of magnetite varies with the tectonic setting, such as stable continents and subduction zones have more magnetite. We also found that the mantle is cooler than previously thought in many places. The presence of  magnetite in cold mantle regions forms a magnetic source to satellite magnetic anomalies that was previously erroneously considered to be in the crust. With this new view our interpretations of the heat distribution in the Earth and thickness of the magnetic crust need to be updated. This is a fundamental change in our understanding of deep magnetic sources in the Earth.

During the course of this project, three graduate students were supported, graduated, and carried on either on an academic career, into the industry or onto a PhD. We disseminated the results of our investigations through 3 articles published in peer-reviewed journals and at multiple professional conferences.
